document.docAuthor: Grubbs, Scott A. & Baumann, Richard W.
document.docTitle: Soyedina sheldoni Grubbs & Baumann 2019, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Soyedina Ricker, 1952 (Plecoptera: Nemouridae) in the eastern Nearctic: review of species concepts, proposed morphology-based species groups, and description of a new species from North Carolina

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Soyedina Ricker, 1952 (Plecoptera: Nemouridae) in the eastern Nearctic: review of species concepts, proposed morphology-based species groups, and description of a new species from North Carolina

subSubSection.paragraph: Description. Macropterous. Male forewing length 4.5–6.0 mm, body length 6.5–8.5 mm (n=26); female forewing length 5.5–6.5 mm , body length 8.5–9.5 mm (n=11). General body color dark brown. Head dark brown except for a lighter medial area extending from the occiput anteriorly to, but not enclosing, the lateral ocelli, and extending into the ocellar triangle ( Fig. 65 ). Legs light brown ( Fig. 65 ). Wings fumose, venation typical for genus with veins A 1 and A 2 united near posterior margin. Cerci membranous ( Fig. 66 ) and single-segmented. Gills absent.

Male. ( Figs. 65–67 ; 69–78 ). 7 th and 8 th abdominal terga unmodified. Hypoproct well-developed, base covering medial ⅓ of 9 th sternum, constricted in basal half to plane of the base of the paraprocts; apical half tapered and set between base of outer paraproct lobes, distally tapered markedly to a lightly-sclerotized, narrowly-triangular terminus. Vesicle base partially obscured on preserved males by posterior margin of 8 th abdominal sternum; narrow basally, widest in medial ½, tapered apically; mean length (L): 0.031 mm , mean maximum width ( MW ): 0.013 mm , mean L/ MW ratio: 2.45 (n=11). Paraprocts with two lobes, inner lobes difficult to discern with standard light microscopy on uncleared specimens, lightly sclerotized and inconspicuous, extending only slightly to base of recurved portion of outer lobes; outer lobes heavily sclerotized, large and robust for genus, in basal half appear bulbous in ventral view ( Fig. 67 ) but essentially medially-concave in dorsal view ( Figs. 66 , 76 ); broadly rounded basally and dorsally ( Figs. 66 , 77–78 ); recurved in anterior 1/3, slightly concave laterally ( Figs. 66 , 69 , 76 ) and dorsally ( Figs. 77–78 ), terminating anteriorly in medially-directed triangular flaps ( Figs. 69–70 , 77–78 ). Epiproct typical for genus, exhibiting asymmetry with right half longer than left ( Figs. 69–70,74 ); lateral arms short and lightly sclerotized, extending from near the distal terminus of the 10 th tergal sclerite to the basal cushion; ventral sclerites elongate and asymmetric, right longer than left ( Figs. 69–70 ), studded with small teeth medially and laterally throughout length, tips typically rounded distally ( Figs. 71–72 ); dorsal sclerite elongate and asymmetric, right longer than left ( Figs. 67 , 69, 73–74 ), appearing scaly at higher magnifications ( Figs. 71–72 ), open apically, revealing an sclerotized inner member is either slightly tapered or straight-sided distally ( Figs. 71–73 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 65–68 .
Soyedina sheldoni
n. sp.
65–66, USA, North Carolina, seeps along Buncombe Trail; 67–68: USA, North Carolina, Lower Creek. 65, male, head and pronotum, dorsal view, 4X; 66, male, abdominal terminalia, dorsal view, 11.5X; 67, male, abdominal terminalia, ventral view, 11.5X; 68, female, abdominal terminalia, ventral view, 5X. ds = dorsal sclerite, vs = ventral sclerite, opl = outer paraproct lobe.

FIGURES 69–74 .
Soyedina sheldoni
n. sp.
69, 71, 73–74, USA, North Carolina, Holder Creek; 70, 72: USA, North Carolina, tributary to Holder Creek. 69, epiproct, ventral view, 200X; 70, epiproct, ventral view, 270X; 71, epiproct apex, ventral view, 650X; 72, epiproct apex, ventral view, 800X; 73, epiproct apex, lateral view, 270X; 74, epiproct, caudal view, 180X. ds = dorsal sclerite, vs = ventral sclerite, im = inner member, opl = outer paraproct lobe.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. The combination of the (a) nearly straight-sided sclerotized inner epiproct member ( Figs. 71–72 ), (b) apically-rounded ventral sclerites ( Figs. 69–70 ), and (c) robust outer paraproct lobe that is medially-concave and has a prominent, anteriorly-directed triangular flap ( Figs. 76–78 ) readily distinguishes
S. sheldoni
sp. nov.
from all other eastern Nearctic
Soyedina
with some form of an anterior projection on the outer paraproct lobe. Several spe- cies of eastern
Soyedina
have a spur or flap present on the outer paraproct lobe. These include
S. amicalola
( Fig. 56 ;
Verdone et al . 2017
, their figs. 5, 8), two distinct phenotypes of
S. carolinensis
( Figs. 33–34 ),
S. kondratieffi
( Figs 63–64 ), the more subtle spur exhibited by
S. merritti
( Fig. 41 ), and the geographically-consistent shape present on
S. washingtoni
( Figs. 49–50 ). Hence, the presence alone of a spur is not diagnostic for species-level determinations of eastern
Soyedina
.

The outer paraproct lobe of
S. sheldoni
sp. nov.
( Figs. 77–78 ) is similar only to
S. amicalola
( Fig. 56 ;
Verdone et al . 2017
, their figs. 5, 8), but two epiproct characteristics distinguish these two species. First, the ventral sclerites of
S. sheldoni
sp. nov.
are typically rounded apically ( Figs. 69–70 ) yet subtriangular on
S. amicalola
( Fig. 51 ). Second, the nr. straight-sided sclerotized inner epiproct member of
S. sheldoni
sp. nov.
( Figs. 71–73 ) is easily distinct from the apically-triangular and caudally-split inner member of
S. amicalola
( Figs. 53–55 ).

Remarks.
Soyedina sheldoni
sp. nov.
is presently known from the southern Appalachian Highlands region in western North Carolina ( Fig. 81 ). The holotype locality and most paratype localities are positioned in the High Mountains Level IV ( 66i ) Ecoregion. This region is characterized by disjunct high-elevation Appalachian landscapes with remnant patches of red spruce (
Picea rubens Sargent, 1898
) and Frasier fir (
Abies fraseri Pursh, 1817
) (
Griffith et al . 2002
).
Paraleuctra sara (Claassen, 1937)
was the only other stonefly species collected with
S. sheldoni
sp. nov.
at the type locality.
